text: Humanity has been trying to create mobility solutions
for the visually impaired for 5,000 years.
But we still use the service dog and the white cane.
300 million visually impaired in the world
but they share the same 28,000 guide dogs.
That's not scalable.
.lumen builds glasses
that do everything a self driving car does
all into something which you can comfortably
wear on your head
in order to guide blind people all over the world.
And to do that, we had to train AI models.
We had to be able to connect
to the products running those AI models,
and that's where AWS helped us.
Navigating the pedestrian world
is actually incredibly complex.
We take for granted how much our brain does
in order to help us go to certain places
to navigate certain obstacles.
So we had to train machine learning models
that work all over the world
regardless of how the world looks like.
That's not trivial because there are so many sensors
and this quantity of data is so large,
10 gigabits of data per minute.
So we need to actually be able to connect to them
all over the world and to get that data
to be able to remotely debug it.
We use IoT core running in AWS infrastructure,
and we use Greengrass directly in the devices
and stay connected to them.
The number one problem, which visually impaired have
towards getting better education or better jobs,
or having a more normal social life is
the mobility towards those places.
This is what we do with the glasses.
We enable that mobility.
